video.title: How to Learn from Free University Courses (Audit Classes Online)
video.description:
Learn how to successfully audit public college computer science courses on the web! 

In this video, students Seth Goldin and Sam Crombie discuss learning on the web, methods for choosing a topic and course, tips to consider when conducting your audit, and more!

🔗 Find your next CS audit resource: https://collegecompendium.org

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Intro
⌨️ (01:41) Learning on the Web
⌨️ (08:35) What is "Auditing" a Course?
⌨️ (13:27) Why Audit Courses?
⌨️ (20:36) Choosing the Right Topic
⌨️ (27:35) Choosing the Right Course
⌨️ (34:49) Making the Most of Your Audit
⌨️ (44:34) Next Steps
⌨️ (47:44) Example Audits
⌨️ (58:38) Outro

Disclaimer: We are two students sharing our insights from our personal experiences about the process of auditing in an effort to potentially help you with your journey. We are not affiliated with any colleges, professors, or courses. 

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Vero Vertex
topLevelComment.text:
There are few notes and comments I want to share, hope you are reading it (given the time I write this a bit later after you guys uploaded the video):

1. Regarding the community thing, you forgot to mention one thing: *_contribute_* . This contribution can be in form of answering question, evaluating courses and report for errors, or sharing your code to the community via github. It is a cyclical process, someone answering your question, and in turn you should answer other question, if you are able to. And do not forget the Feynman Method: The best way to learn is by teaching it. Once you are able to explain or answer others question, your understanding is cemented in your mind. This also will build the community better.

2. Its also better to include how to audit courses on Youtube. Sometimes videos in YT channels such as in freeCodeCamp channel is hours long and sometimes cannot be finished in one sitting. Fortunately, FCC provided timestamps so that we can return to our learning later. But the problem is how to manage your study if it is not structured like MOOCs, but rather just a pile of YT videos? I found that that theme is worth explaining too, and besides, you uploaded this video in FCC right? Lol 🤣🤣🤣.

Thank you for your amazing video, Seth and Sam! I think it is really an introductory course on learning online, which is as you described really different with in-class learning. I myself currently doing a masters, my topic is in e-learning and edtech (my research topic is in Self-Regulated Learning, which you guys amazingly covered, ten thumbs up for you guys 👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍👍). And find myself need to revisiting my college algebra understanding to learn data science before delving into learning analytics. Hope you guys are successful in your study!

topLevelComment.author: The Hacker
topLevelComment.text:
There is a difference between learning, and being recognized for having proper certification. 
People with certs _can be_ idiots, while everyone here who is learning because they want to learn, probably won't be hired due to not having proper certification.

replies.author: Miss desire Independance
replies.text: You can combine these courses with a degree. Your employer will view it as continuing education.

replies.author: Silent_Simulator
replies.text: @illb2fast4u of couse you judged people... "people who dont need their hand held.." Always the same...those thinking that they are superior are insulting the "inferior" ... but quickly forget about it and dont admit it even happened. The next is, again always the same way : They are accusing their critics to  suffer from an inferiority complex. just turning the table to hide your not polite attitude..I dont care who you are or what you do , just dont judge people you dont know. Just because the op said there is a difference between "just learning" and "proper certification" doesnt mean that you can come up and tell the world that those "self employed" dont need certifications. You know what? Most people in the world..depends on their countries of course..dont even got the chance of being self employed..and there in such life circumstances it makes a fucking big difference if you "learned something on the internet" or got a certicfication. Because in most countries that counts more than the abilities you really got..

replies.author: illb2fast4u
replies.text: @Silent_Simulator I didn't say I'm better than anyone. You seem to suffer from an inferiority complex. I stated the obvious. People who don't need to be spoon-fed, are generally self employed and as such we study only what is required, when it is required, for a specific purpose. We deliver projects and move on. We don't have time of the need to wave around tons of certificates and qualifications in the hopes that we impress somebody, who might employ us. PS: Generally we aren't impressed by stacks of paper either. We want to know; What projects did you do, what was your stake in the project, what was the flight plan and did you deliver ahead of schedule, on time or past the deployment date? If you went past the employment date, why? What roadblocks did you experience and what did you do to get around it. We know not all projects can be landed bang-on-time, in fact in the current world situation, they very seldom do. How you navigated your road to completion is way more important. Now tell me, in which set structure of learning do you have to deal with these variables? That my friend is why we do not care. PS: I never said I don't have any formal qualifications from an accredited University. I said employers do not care what your qualifications are if you can do the job. I have qualifications from formal Universities, but again, that was done through distance learning too. Certificates are overrated. Sitting whole day for years on end only studying is a form of procrastination.

replies.author: Silent_Simulator
replies.text: @Martin McLean yeah..I don't think I'm better than anyone else just because I'm self employed or some other unimportant fact. Don't like it? Gtfo..be an a** and think you are better than other people....

replies.text: @Silent_Simulator well you show us which one you are, now didn't you.

topLevelComment.author: Peter Sedesse
topLevelComment.text: meh, not really a fan of this one.  Auditing a class at a university is worse than using something like FCC or SoloLearn where at least you have a community of people to brainstorm with.  Also University professors are very likely far behind with tech.  So yeah, maybe if you want C++ or java classes it might be fine.  Also, if you audit classes, you can't really tell anyone you audited them.  You don't get transcripts, none of your work is graded or even looked at by anyone compared to online tools where you get feedback.

topLevelComment.author: Wapohead
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks for the time and effort you fellas put in to this vid. I don't know if this helped me decide or made me more frustrated. 
I have been in entertainment for 30yrs and have a love/hate relationship with the industry in general - I even own my own company in an Asian country.
When I was 28, I thought I knew it all. I turned 30 and realized I didn't know squat. With each passing decade, it's compounding. I am turning 50 soon and want to learn absolutely everything! Since I am technically savvy, due to the nature of my profession, I build my own pc rigs and love troubleshooting. So sticking with pc related learning just seems logical. I am thinking Python coding first, but then I read or see something on AI or robotics and want to study those also - the list is endless.

I love all sciences. And just like pc learning, I want to learn geology to quantum physics. I have sooooo many started audits and none completed.

If I were to focus (extremely hard to do) on just pc related learning and say a programming language, where would you suggest I start? Anyone please chime in ;) Thanks in advance!!
BTW, I also have three kids and very irregular work hours.

topLevelComment.author: ath
topLevelComment.text: These are all amazing materials and important to be addressed, but the presentation missed out on key limitations of auditing courses. Also, auditing typically being already enrolled as a student in an institution while taking a course that you’re not so sure you would like it. Auditing a course is generally still associated with tuition cost, unless the professor allows you to “sit in” the class. The definition of “auditing” mentioned in this video really means “take a free and open course offered by a university” rather than non-university, which is wonderful, but very different from the typical meaning of “auditing “ in higher education. One will be quite disappointed to find out that auditing is not as simple as the video suggested.

replies.author: Counterfluxed
replies.text: @ASS No, he’s right that you won’t get any certification

replies.author: ASS
replies.text: @Counterfluxed  so can we take a certificate for completing such an audited course

replies.author: Counterfluxed
replies.text: It does say at 8:50 "In the American university system, “auditing” is traditionally when you take a course offered by an institution for no credit or grade. This primarily encompasses attending lectures without participating in examinations in an effort to learn more about a particular topic. Depending on the institution or platform, you’re able to access assignments or projects to work on independently without receiving feedback. Auditing a class may also require official instructor permission." which seems to cover that

topLevelComment.author: vivek upadhyay
topLevelComment.text: Learnig on the internet is so much better than college learning.

replies.author: V - Sig
replies.text: Sometimes college, or a private school, can be a good kickstart / relaunch, the main advantage being : you have people aproximately like you in the same situation; you have real humans as professors, sometimes in the real industry.

replies.author: Abdullah
replies.text: @vivek upadhyay tbh getting a college degree is needed in the current world to get a job, so I dont blame you. However, having free education online available for everyone is a win!

replies.author: LLouG
replies.text: @vivek upadhyay tbf having a college degree may give you some kind of advantage when you attempt to get hired by a company, personally I don't have the patience to stay inside a classroom, but with online classes getting more and more common I feel like eventually I won't be able to avoid it anymore(not a bad thing though).

replies.author: vivek upadhyay
replies.text:
@LLouG But this may sound hypocritical, but I am also in college for Bachelor in Computer Science.
But I agree that online learning is much better it's just that I'm in college just for the degree. 😅

replies.author: LLouG
replies.text: Right? It gives us so much freedom to learn at our own pace.
